title: Pre-dawn planet dance
text:
Pre-dawn planet dance 0 comments 
The lunar eclipse of Sept 27-28, 2015, has come and gone, and for many of us cloudy skies meant nothing to see. I did hear reports of eclipse sightings through broken clouds from Gettysburg, Lake Heritage, and Frederick County. A nice photo by student Stephen Brown of the partially eclipsed moon with Glatfelter Hall in the foreground was posted on Gettysburg College's Instagram account. So far as I have seen, his were the only local photos. 
The good news for this month is that the prime sky event-a dance of Venus, Jupiter, and Mars in the predawn sky-has a longer window of opportunity. If you head out to a place with a flat eastern horizon an hour before sunrise tomorrow, you'll see Venus about 30 degrees up. It's brilliant! Just below it and to the left is Jupiter. Though not as bright as Venus, it should still be plainly visible. Below Jupiter, and only a finger-width away, is Mars, which is fainter than the other two planets. You should be able to cover the whole group with your outstretched palm. If you have clear skies and a really flat horizon, look for Mercury almost due east and only a few degrees above the horizon. Binoculars will help pick it out of the predawn glow. kAm%96 H@C5 Q52?46Q :>A=:6D >@G6>6?E] w6C6 :D 9@H E9:D 8C@FA:?8 @7 A=2?6ED H:== 492?86 @G6C E96 ?6IE 76H H66<D] |6C4FCJ 2?5 '6?FD 2C6 3@E9 C@F?5:?8 :?E@ E96 72C D:56 @7 E96:C @C3:ED 7C@> @FC A6CDA64E:G6j E96J H:== 36 D:?<:?8 5@H?
